titleStmt.title: Catalytic promiscuity enabled by photoredox catalysis in nicotinamide-dependent oxidoreductases

analytic.title: Catalytic promiscuity enabled by photoredox catalysis in nicotinamide-dependent oxidoreductases

div.p: Unless otherwise noted, all chemicals and reagents for chemical reactions were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received (Sigma-Aldrich and VWR). GDH-105 and KRED-P2-D03 were purchased from Codexis as cell free lysates and used as received. Silica gel chromatography purifications were carried out using AMD Silica Gel 60. 1 H-and 13 C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker UltraShield Plus (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument, and are internally referenced to residual proton signals in CDCl 3 (7.26 ppm). Data for 1 H-NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift (δ ppm), multiplicity (s = singlet, brs = broad singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, m = multiplet, dd = doublet of doublet, dt = doublet of triplet, ddd = doublet of doublet of doublet), coupling constant (Hz), and integration. Data for 13 C NMR are reported in terms of chemical shift relative to CDCl 3 (77 ppm). High-resolution mass spectra were obtained on an Agilent 6220 LC/MS with an electrospray ionization time-of-flight (ESI-TOF) detector. Lotus Separations LLC at Princeton University, isolated single enantiomers of some starting materials and products using SFC.

Chromatography. Analytical high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was carried out using an Agilent 1260 Infinity LCMS System. Yields and conversions were determined on a Poroshell C18 column (4.6mm x 50 mm, 2.7 micron) against an internal standard as indicated. Analytical chiral HPLC was conducted using an Agilent 1260 Infinity Chiral HPLC system with isopropanol and hexanes as the mobile phase. Chiral IA, IB, IC, ID, and OJ-H columns were used to separate enantiomers (4.6 x 250 mm, 5 μm). Chiral GC was performed on an α-Dex120 column from Supelco (RTX5, 37625-04A) Cyclic Voltammetry. Electrochemical studies were carried out in a 25 mL three-necked flask at the given concentrations. All potentials were measured using a CH Instruments Electrochemical Workstation potentiostat, and were measured against a saturated calomel reference electrode (SCE). Before each measurement, the glassy carbon working electrode was polished with 50 nm alumina powder and rinsed with deionized water; the platinum wire counter electrode was flame activated prior to measurement.

Cloning. pET22b(+) was used as a cloning and expression vector for all enzymes described in this study. Genes for Nicotiana tabacum DBR (NtDBR), P. appendiculatum DBR 1 (PaDBR1), P. appendiculatum DBR 2 (PaDBR2), and A. thaliana DBR 1 (AtDBR1) were purchased as gBlocks from IDT and cloned using Gibson Cloning. 1 All genes were cloned between the NdeI and Xhol restriction sites and contained a Cterminal 6xHis tag. Cloning for each construct was carried out using DH5α E. coli.

div.head: DBR Protein Expression.
div.p: Enzymes used in purified protein experiments were expressed in BL21(DE3) E. coli cultures transformed with plasmid encoding DBR variants. Transformed glycerol stocks were used to initiate 50 mL overnight cultures (37 ºC, 250 rpm). Expression cultures (500 mL of TB with ampicillin (100 μg/ml final

div.head: Table of Contents
div.p: concentration) in a 2L flask) were inoculated with 6.25 ml of the overnight culture and grown to OD 600 = 0.7 -1.1 (37 ºC, 250 rpm). Expression was induced with IPTG (0.5 mM) and allowed to express for 24 h (18 ºC, 250 rpm). Following expression, cells were pelleted and frozen at -20 °C. For purification, frozen cells were resuspended in buffer A (50 mM TRIS, 10 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, pH=8.0) and disrupted by sonication (2 x 4 min, output control 5, 35% duty cycle; Sonicator QSonica Q500 Ultra Sonicator). To pellet insoluble material, lysates were centrifuged at 14,000 x g for 1.0 h at 4 °C. Proteins were purified using a nickel NTA column (5 mL HisTrap HP, GE Healthcare, Piscataway, NJ) using an AKTAStart purifier FPLC system (GE healthcare). DBR enzymes were eluted with 100 % buffer B (50 mM TRIS, 300 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, pH=8.0) over 5 column volumes. Fractions containing DBR enzymes were pooled, concentrated, and subjected to three exchanges of TRIS buffer (50 mM TRIS, 10% glycerol, pH=8.0) to remove excess salt and imidazole. Concentrated (0.7-1.1 mM) proteins were aliquoted, flash-frozen in liquid N 2 , and stored at -80 °C until later use. Protein concentration was determined by A 280 with calculated extinction coefficients.

Extinction Coefficients related to the study herein: (Determined using the ExPASy ProtParam tool: http://web.expasy.org/protparam/ ) NtDBR: 84205 M -1 cm -1 (dimeric) PaDBR1: 83660 M -1 cm -1 PaDBR2: 86640 M -1 cm -1 AtDBR1: 81600 M -1 cm -1

div.head: General Procedures for Substrate Synthesis
div.p: General α-Oxidation Procedure (General Procedure A):

Based on the α-oxidation procedure of Jiao et al. 2 , a round bottom flask was charged with starting ketone (1 equiv), Cs 2 CO 3 (0.2 equiv) and a magnetic stir bar. The flask was then equipped with an oxygen balloon and placed under mild vacuum for two minutes to ensure an oxygen-rich environment. The vacuum outlet was then removed and the flask was charged with P(OEt) 3 (2 equiv) and DMSO (20 mL/gram of starting ketone). The resulting mixture was stirred for 15 h at which point the reaction mixture was poured into a separatory funnel containing brine (20 mL/gram of starting ketone). The crude product was extracted with EtOAc (40 mL/ gram of starting ketone x 3), dried with Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo to afford crude product. The crude product was purified via flash chromatography.

div.head: General Acylation Procedure (General Procedure B):
div.p: A solution of starting ketone (1 equiv) and Ac 2 O (40 mL/ gram of starting material) was treated with H 2 SO 4 (100 μL/ gram of starting alcohol). The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min (monitored to completion by TLC) and the resulting solution was subsequently concentrated in vacuo and purified via flash chromatography. Yield: 93% (General Procedure A); 99% (General Procedure B)

To the resulting solution was added 10% palladium on carbon (50 wt%) at room temperature. Ammonium formate (1.5 equiv) was added and the reaction was stirred at room temperature for 12 hours open to air. The mixture was filtered through Celite ® and the cake was washed with EtOAc and the solvent was removed in vacuo. The residue was dissolved in 1M NaOH and washed with EtOAc. The aqueous layers were retained, acidified with 12M HCl and extracted with EtOAc. The organic extracts were washed with brine, dried over MgSO 4 , filtered and concentrated to give a colorless oil. Yield: 80% 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 7.36 -7.28 (m, 2H), 7.29 -7.18 (m, 3H), 3.11 (dd, J = 13.5, 6.5 Hz, 1H), 2.86 -2.74 (m, 1H), 2.70 (dd, J = 13.5, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 1.21 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H). 13 C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 182.45, 139.02, 129.02, 128.44, 126.44, 41.23, 39.27. div.head: General Procedure C (Amide Formation)
div.p: 2-methyl-3-phenyl propionic acid (1.0 equiv) was dissolved in dry DCM in a sealed flask fitted with an outlet needle and cooled to 0 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. Two drops of dry DMF were added at 0 °C. Oxalyl chloride (1.1 equiv) was added dropwise at 0 °C (Note: gases evolve during this addition) and the reaction was stirred for 1h while warming to room temperature. Solvent was removed in vacuo and the crude product was dried under vacuum for 1 hour and used in the next step without further purification.

The crude acid chloride product was dissolved in dry DCM and cooled to 0 °C. Amine (2.5 equiv) was added dropwise and the reaction was stirred for 2 h while warming to room temperature. The reaction was quenched with 1M HCl and extracted with DCM.
The organic extracts were washed with 1M HCl, water and brine, dried over MgSO 4 , filtered and concentrated to give analytically pure product.

div.head: General Procedure D (Bromination of Amides)
div.p: Diisopropylamine (1.05 equiv) was dissolved in 5 mL dry THF and cooled to -78 °C. nBuLi (1 equiv) was added dropwise and the solution was stirred at -78 °C for 30 minutes. The amide product from the previous step dissolved in 1 mL dry THF was added and stirred at -78 °C for 1 hour. TMSCl (1.05 equiv) dissolved in 1 mL dry THF was added and the mixture was warmed to room temperature over 3 hours. The mixture was cooled to -78 °C and NBS (1.5 equiv) was added and stirred for 1 hour at -78 °C before being warmed to room temperature over 1 hour. The reaction was quenched with water, and the aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc. The organic extracts were washed with brine, dried over MgSO 4 , filtered and concentrated in vacuo to give the crude product which was purified by flash column chromatography.

div.head: 2-bromo-N, N-diethyl-2-methyl-3-phenylpropionamide (31):
div.p: Synthesized from 2methyl-3-phenylpropionic acid and diethylamine according to General Procedures C and D.
Yield: (General Procedure C) 51% (General Procedure D) 29%

div.head: 2-bromo-2-methyl-3-phenyl-1-(pyrrolidin-1-yl) propan-1-one (32):
div.p: Synthesized from 2-methyl-3-phenylpropionic acid and pyrrolidine according to General Procedures C and D.
Yield: (General Procedure C) = 40% (General Procedure D) = 31%

div.head: Synthesis and Characterization of α-Bromolactones
div.p: General Procedure E (Lactone Formation):

LDA was prepared by dropwise addition of nBuLi (1.1 equiv) to diisopropylamine (1.1 equiv) at 0 °C. This was stirred for 30 min at 0 °C and then cooled to -78 °C, at which time ester (1 equiv) was added dropwise, followed by stirring for 1 h. Etheylene sulfate (1.1 equiv) was added all at once and the solution was allowed to gradually warm up to room temperature. Solvent was removed and the residue was redissolved in 1:1 toluene: 5% H 2 SO 4 and refluxed overnight. The mixture is cooled to room temp and the layers are separated and extracted with EtOAc. The organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na 2 SO 4 , filtered and concentrated. Crude product was purified using flash chromatography.

div.head: General Procedure F (Bromination of Lactones):
div.p: Diisopropylamine (1.2 equiv) was dissolved in THF at 0 °C to which nBuLi (1.2 equiv) was added. The resulting solution was stirred for 1 h. The solution was cooled to -78 °C and lactone (1 equiv) was added dropwise, followed by an additional 30 mins of stirring. TMSCl (1.2 equiv) was added and stirred for 3 h while warming to room temperature.

The mixture was again cooled to -78 °C followed by the addition of NBS (1.2 equiv). The reaction mixture was then stirred for 1 h, and allowed to warm to room temperature over 1 h. The reaction was quenched wtih satd NH 4 Cl and extracted with EtOAc. Combined extracts were washed with brine, dried with Na 2 SO 4 , and concentrated in vacuo. The crude residue was purified with column chromatography.
3-allyl-3-bromodihydrofuran-2(3H)-one (34): Synthesized from methyl pent-4-enoate according to General Procedures E and F.
Yield: 80% (General Procedure E); 65% (General Procedure F)

div.head: Enantioselective Deacetoxylation of α-Acetoxyketones using DBRs
div.p: General Procedure:

A 4 mL shell vial was charged with a magnetic stir bar and glucose (6 equiv) and transferred into an anaerobic chamber. A solution of GDH-105 (0.2 mg/mg substrate) in KPi buffer (100 mM KPi, 10% glycerol, pH = 8, 182 μL/ mg substrate) was added to the vial containing glucose, resulting in a homogenous solution. To this solution was added enzyme (1 mol%), followed by sequential addition of a solution of NADP + (1 mol%, 5 mg/mL solution) in KPi buffer (100 mM KPi, 10% glycerol, pH = 8, 5 mg/mL solution) and a solution of Rose Bengal (0.5 mol%, 5 mg/mL solution) in KPi buffer (100 mM KPi, 10% glycerol, pH = 8, 5 mg/mL solution), resulting in a magenta solution. Finally, a solution of substrate in degassed 2:1-THF:EtOH (10 μL/ mg substrate) was added to the vial. The vial was sealed with a septum and removed from the anaerobic chamber. The vial was placed in a fan-cooled crystallization dish laced with 530 nm LEDs (2 x 0.5M 12 VDC Green LEDs 60LEDs/M purchased from superbrightlights.com) and was subsequently equipped with a nitrogen inlet and outlet (see below). The resulting solution was stirred under a gentle stream of nitrogen for 5 min, at which point the outlet was removed and the reaction was kept under a positive stream of nitrogen via strictly the inlet needle. The green LEDs were then turned on and the reaction was allowed to stir for 12 h. 1 H-NMR (500 MHz; CDCl 3 ): δ 8.03 (dd, J = 7.8, 1.1 Hz, 1H), 7.45 (td, J = 7.5, 1.4 Hz, 1H), 7.30 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.23 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 3.03-2.97 (m, 2H), 2.51-2.46 (m, 1H), 2.24 (dq, J = 13.3, 4.9 Hz, 1H), 1.95-1.85 (m, 2H), 1.52-1.37 (m, 3H), 0.96 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13 C-NMR (126 MHz; CDCl 3 ): δ 200.7, 144.1, 133.2, 132.7, 128.8, 127.6, 126.7, 47.4, 31.7, 28.43, 28.29, 20.3, 14.3. IR: 1686.0, 1463.5, 1267.7, 1049.6 cm -1 Enantioselective Dehalogenation of α-Bromoketones and Amides using KREDs General Procedure (Enzymatic Reactions): A 4 mL shell vial was charged with a magnetic stir bar and ketoreductase P2-DO3 (4.8 mg, 1 mol %) and transferred into an anaerobic chamber. A solution of reconstituted Codexis P-Mix (4.8mg in 900μL H 2 O, 1.2 mol% NADP + ) was added to the vial containing enzyme. Photocatalyst (0.125 mol% in aqueous 2 mg/mL solution), and i-PrOH (100 μL) were added to the reaction, followed by a solution of substrate in degassed DMSO (0.007 mmol substrate in 25μL DMSO). The vial was sealed with a septum and removed from the anaerobic chamber. The vial was placed in a fan-cooled crystallization dish (125 mm x 65 mm) laced with 460nm LEDs (2 x 0.5M 12 VDC Blue LEDs 60 LEDs/M purchased from superbrightleds.com Part Number NFLS-X3-LC2) and stirred for 24 hours.

div.head: Supplementary
div.p: Yield Determination. The reaction was quenched with 0.01M internal standard (1mL) in HPLC grade acetonitrile. 1 mL of that mixture was placed in an Eppendorf tube, vortexed, and centrifuged at 14000 rpm for 5 minutes. Yield was determined by reverse phase LCMS using an internal standard against a standard curve of independently synthesized product.

Enantiomeric Ratio Determination. One half of the reaction mixture was set aside and quenched with 1mL ethyl acetate. The organic layer was passed through MgSO 4 , concentrated in vacuo and redissolved in either 1:1 hexanes/isopropanol to a concentration of 1 mg/mL. Enantiomeric ratios were determined using chiral HPLC. 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 7.22 -7.15 (m, 2H), 7.11 (tt, J = 6.4, 1.1 Hz, 3H), 3.40 -3.26 (m, 2H), 3.21 (dt, J = 10.1, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.89 (ddd, J = 17.3, 13.5, 7.7 Hz, 2H), 2.71 (dp, J = 8.3, 6.6 Hz, 1H), 2.58 (dd, J = 13.1, 6.4 Hz, 1H), 1.78 -1.54 (m, 2H), 1.09 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 3H). 13 C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 174.40, 140.23, 129.00, 128.24, 126.16, 40.47, 17.42. 10.8, 7.4, 3.8 Hz, 1H), 3.22 -3.13 (m, 1H), 3.07 -2.92 (m, 4H), 2.72 (q, J = 9.9 Hz, 1H), 1.20 (d, J = 5.9 Hz, 3H).

13 C NMR (126 MHz, CDCl 3 ): δ 174.46, 139.90, 129.06, 128.44, 126.42, 66.80, 18.06. IR: 1625.9; 1542.1; 1433.1; 1112.5; 1230.6; 726.4; 699.9 ESI: HRMS calculated for C 14 H 19 NO 2 = 233.14158. Found = 233.14195. In accordance with the literature protocol 13 , LiOtBu (1.00 mmol), Pd 2 (dba) 3 (0.0025 mmol), and Q-phos (0.005 mmol) were added to a flame-dried flask under N 2 atmosphere. Atmosphere exchanges were performed after addition of each solid by putting the reaction vessel under vacuum and replacing with fresh N 2 . Dry, degassed tetrahydrofuran (0.25 M) was added with stirring at rt. Ketone (0.25 mmol) is added dropwise. After 5 min of stirring, bromo alkene is added and stirred until complete by TLC (ca. 20-30 minutes). The reaction mixture is diluted with EtOAc, passed through a silica plug with EtOAc as eluent, and concentrated. Purification on silica gel with a 3% EtOAc 97% hexane mobile phase affords product (81%).

div.head: 2-(2,2-dimethylcyclopropyl)-1-(3-methoxyphenyl)ethan-1-one (28):
div.p: In accordance with the literature protocol 14 , to freshly distilled DCM in a flame-dried flask was added diethyl zinc (2 equiv) under N 2 atmosphere. The solution was cooled in an ice bath and a solution of TFA (2.0 M in DCM) was added very slowly to the reaction mixture via syringe. Upon stirring for 20 min, a solution of CH 2 I 2 (2.0 M in DCM) was added dropwise. After an additional 20 min of stirring, a solution of alkene (1.0 M in DCM) was added, and the ice bath was removed. After an additional (approx. 30 min) of stirring, (check TLC) the reaction was quenched with saturated NH 4 Cl and hexanes, and the layers were separated. The aqueous layer was extracted with hexanes. Combined organics are washed with saturated NaHCO 3 , water, brine, and then dried with Na 2 SO 4 . Filtration to remove Na 2 SO 4 and rotary evaporation to remove solvent yields a crude product, which is purified by column chromatography with silica gel to yield the product as a clear oil (63%).

13 C-NMR (126 MHz; CDCl 3 ): δ 200.4, 159.9, 138.5, 129.7, 120.9, 119.5, 112.4, 76.9, 55.6, 39.5, 27.3, 20.4, 19.91, 19.86, 15.6. HRMS: Calcd for C 14 H 19 O 2 (M+H) 219.1385, Found 219.1387. IR: 1682.9, 1581.8, 1427.8, 1251.6 cm -1 28 O MeO Me Me 1-(2,2-dimethylcyclopropyl)-2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-oxoethyl acetate (27): In accordance with the literature protocol 15 , in a flame-dried flask under inert atmosphere with a stir bar was added THF and KHMDS (1.5 equiv). After being cooled to -78 °C, 1.0 equiv of ketone is added, and the solution is allowed to stir at -78 °C for 15-30 min, followed by the addition of 3-phenyl-2-(phenylsulfonyl)-1,2-oxaziridine (1.5 equiv) as a 0.06 M solution in THF. After stirring for approximately 20 min (monitor by TLC), the reaction is quenched at -78 °C by addition of 1-2 mL saturated NH 4 Cl solution. The solvent is removed by rotary evaporation and the residue extracted into ether. Passing this through a silica plug afforded crude alcohol, which is acetylated directly in a subsequent step.

To a solution of acetic anhydride (1.5 equiv), triethylamine (1.5 equiv), and DMAP (8 mol%) in DCM (0.5 M) was added alcohol (1 eq). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 15 h and then was quenched by the addition of saturated NH 4 Cl. The aqueous layer is extracted with ether, and the combined organics are washed with brine. Organic layers are dried with MgSO 4 , and are removed by rotary evaporation. The residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel using a 20% EtOAc 80% Hexane gradient to yield the product as a clear oil (71%). 13 C-NMR (126 MHz; CDCl 3 ): δ 197.0, 170.8, 159.8, 136.4, 129.6, 121.2, 120.0, 112.8, 76.2, 55.5, 26.7, 25.2, 20.94, 20.89, 18.9, 17.7. 27 O MeO Me Me OAc (E)-1-(3-methoxyphenyl)-5-methylhex-2-en-1-one:

In accordance with the literature protocol 16 , A stirred solution of isovaleraldehyde (0.861 mmol, 1 equiv) and known Wittig reagent 1-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(triphenylphosphoranylidene)ethanone (1.033 mmol, 1.2 equiv) in CHCl 3 (3.31 mL, 0.26 M) were heated at 80 °C overnight. After consumption of the starting material (as indicated by TLC), the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified on silica using a mobile phase consisting of 5% EtOAc in hexanes to yield the product enone as a clear oil (55%).

CV Experiments 20 mL of 1 mM Rose Bengal solution is prepared in a three-necked 25 mL round bottom flask using 100 mM KCl buffer with 10% glycerol (pH 8). This is degassed thoroughly with N 2 for 30 minutes. Septa are used to plug the necks of the flask as it is transferred to the potentiostat for analysis. Glassy carbon is used as the working electrode against the saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference. A platinum wire is used as the counter electrode. The working electrode is polished using 50 nm alumina powder and the counter electrode is flame-activated prior to use. CV was commenced using a range of scan rates in the reductive direction with 0 V as the initial potential and -1.8 V and +1.8 V as the low and high potentials, respectively, with a total of four sweep segments.

In a 1 mM solution of Rose Bengal a reduction is seen at -0.9 V as expected given the known reduction potential for ground state Rose Bengal. An oxidative peak seen during the anodic wave indicates that the formation of Rose Bengal radical anion is reversible under these conditions. When an equimolar amount of 2-Me 2-OAc tetralone substrate 1 is added (bottom waveform) and CV is performed with the same parameters listed above a catalytic wave is not observed. The reduction of Rose Bengal occurs as before, followed by the two peak reduction of the substrate (the second peak is likely a result of reduction of the α-keto radical generated upon loss of acetate after the first reduction at -1.3 V). The oxidation peak for regeneration of ground state Rose Bengal reappears but no oxidation peaks are observed for the substrate, consistent with a non-reversible deacetoxylation process that results from single electron reduction. The lack of an observed catalytic wave upon reduction of Rose Bengal in the presence of substrate illustrates that the reduced form of the dye is incapable of undergoing electron transfer with the α-acetoxy ketone substrate without enzyme present. Also notable is the observation of the peak corresponding to the oxidation of RB radical anion in the presence of substrate. Instead of reducing the substrate, its re-oxidation by the electrode is visible.
Quantitative 13 C-NMR: zoom of above: O Me D S113 2 H-NMR: O Me D
potentialof H + /H• in water (57.6 kcal mol -1 ) 28 , one can derive an approximate value of the tetralone ketyl radical O-H BDFE using the following equation 11 :

Based on this approximation, the phenol is more basic than the ketyl radical by approximately 15 pKa units. The calculation accurately places the proton on the phenol rather than the ketyl radical anion.

Knapp's work calculates that the potential of Q B in the absence of a hydrogen bond to D1-Ser264 is -227 mV, whereas upon hydrogen bonding this potential is estimated to be -95 to -62 mV. This shift corresponds to a shift in redox potential of +132 and +165 mV respectively, both in excellent agreement with the estimated shift of +157 mV in the phenol-tetralone system. These shifts mirror the measured differential in redox potential between the "high potential" and "low potential" conformers of plastiquinone Q A of 145 mV 29 , which Knapp proposes differ by a single hydrogen bond to D2-Thr217. In addition, these estimates strongly corroborate recent theoretical studies of hydrogen bonding to plastoquinones by Noguchi which demonstrate that each additional hydrogen bond to a plastoquinone model species influences the potential by +100-200 mV 30 . Taken together, experimental and theoretical studies of plastoquinone redox potentials as a function of hydrogen bonding provide reasonable agreement to the estimated shift in potential of the model tetralone substrate upon the addition of a single hydrogen bond.

div.head: Stern-Volmer Quenching Studies
div.p: Six separate samples in quartz cuvettes are prepared, each containing 2 mL of 1 μM Rose Bengal with varying amounts of quencher (0, 2.5, 5, 7.5, 10, 12.5 mol% or 0-250 nM in 50 nM increments), in a Coy chamber with fresh catalysts and a strictly anaerobic atmosphere. The cuvettes are sealed and wrapped with parafilm before transferring to the spectrometer. Rose Bengal is excited at 525 nm, while monitoring the emission counts of triplet Rose Bengal at 713 nm 18 . Each data point is collected in triplicate and the average count value is used.

div.head: Computational Evaluation of Redox Modulation via Hydrogen Bonding
Computational Details
div.p: All calculations used DFT methodology 19 as implemented in the Gaussian 16 series of computer programs 1 . We employed the unrestricted ωB97XD functional, 20 with choice of density functional informed by its performance in describing hydrogen bond interaction energies. 21 All-electron, split-valence triple-ζ plus polarization and diffuse functions 6-311G++(2d,2p) basis sets were used 22 . Solvation was modeled using the SMD model with the solvent as water 23 . All complexes underwent geometry optimization, and stationary points were subjected to normal mode analysis. Supplementary Figure 13. Chemical equation for thermodynamic analysis of the change in redox potential upon hydrogen bonding. In lieu of tyrosine, 4-methylphenol is used as a truncated substitute. Me Supplementary Figure 14. Thermodynamic stationary points for hydrogen bonding analysis and energetic analysis of the reaction. For stationary points, energies are given in hartree and entropy is provided in entropy units. For the energetic analysis, the electronic energies, enthalpies, and free energies are given in units kcal mol -1 using the conversion factor 627.51 kcal mol -1 per hartree and are rounded off after the third decimal place. The change in potential is derived from the free energy of the reaction using the conversion factor 1000 mV = -23.06 kcal mol -1 . Reduction of the hydrogenbound tetralone is estimated to be downhill, thereby necessitating a positive shift in the redox potential.

div.head: Comments on the Hydrogen Bond Environment and Shift in Potential
div.p: Examination of the 3.0 Å resolution crystal structure 24 of Photosystem II (PSII) by Knapp 25 demonstrates the presence of a hydrogen bond between plastoquinone Q B and D1-Ser264; in the 3.0 Å resolution crystal structure this bond features an O-O distance of 2.8 Å, an O-H distance of 1.9 Å, and a dihedral angle of 55 degrees. These geometric factors are in excellent agreement with our model system and indicate an accurate description of hydrogen bonding to the tetralone.

Based on the structure, the proton is localized on the phenol residue. In water, the pKa of tyrosine is ~10 pKa units. Using the O-H bond strength of the acetophenone ketyl radical (26 kcal mol -1 ) 26
